poem:
Holiday Hacks

In the Sunday paper,  
a chorus of packing cubes and multi-strap bras  
sings practical advice for the fervent traveler:  
a roadmap to sanity through organized luggage,  
beachside wisdom in a bottle of sunscreen,  
tiny hands stay busy with window stickers  
as landscapes blur past—  
the curated chaos of a summer well-spent.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "From packing cubes to multi-strap bras: the holiday hacks you swear by It’s high holiday season, and whether you’re heading to the coast, a city or the hills, a bit of pre-trip prep can go a long way. To help you pack more thoughtfully, make the most of the beach, and stay sane on long journeys with small people, we’ve asked for your best holiday tips – and rounded up the best of our own,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
